element.name: Just Like Joe by orangetigerprawn, Multi-cache (2/2)

long-description.center: A MILLENNIUM-inspired project, which saw the transformation of the area known as Joe’s Bridge in Lusk, was officially unveiled in June 2000. The bridge is located about half-mile north of Lusk, on the way to Skerries and had been hidden for years by hedges, brambles and long grass. The Tidy Towns Committee, as part of their continued efforts to improve the approach roads to the village, decided to tidy up the area and on clearing it, a fine parapet of dressed stone was discovered.

With the blessing and co-operation of Fingal County Council, the committee levelled and grassed the site and river bank, planted trees and built a rockery. The area was called Joe’s Bridge after local man, Joe Sweetman, who often used to sit there some years ago.
To commemorate the occasion a stone was laid on the site with an inscription, but you'll have to visit the site to find out what it says.
To work out the cache location find the following information from the inscription on the commemoration stone.
A. The number of vowels in the 6th word.
B. The number of punctuation marks in the two larger scripts
C. The number of letters in the first word carved in the smallest script size
The final cache location is approximately 2km away. The cache is a quarter litre container. Please upload a photo of yourself doing it just like Joe.

element.encoded-hints: Looking back at Sodom. Was it worth it?

ul.li:
2010-05-23T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
Found this cache on a quick visit to Lusk. We had worked out the stages on a previous visit but hadn't found the final. TFTC Toffee Man #355

2010-05-23T19:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Found this while visiting my sister in Lusk. TFTC #351

2010-05-15T19:00:00Z : Found it by Alastair74
Found with Wildfowler while spending the day in Dublin for the WWFM. TFTC

2010-05-15T19:00:00Z : Found it by wildfowler
Found on a caching weekend around Dublin with Alastair74! TNLNSL TFTC

2010-03-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by merann
Found it this time without any bother after correcting our mistakes from the previous week. SL. TFTC, Merann.

wpt.name: GC1ZXK9
wpt.desc: Just Like Joe by orangetigerprawn, Multi-cache (2/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Just Like Joe
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
A MILLENNIUM-inspired project, which saw the transformation of the area known as Joe’s Bridge in Lusk, was officially unveiled in June 2000. The bridge is located about half-mile north of Lusk, on the way to Skerries and had been hidden for years by hedges, brambles and long grass. The Tidy Towns Committee, as part of their continued efforts to improve the approach roads to the village, decided to tidy up the area and on clearing it, a fine parapet of dressed stone was discovered.






With the blessing and co-operation of Fingal County Council, the committee levelled and grassed the site and river bank, planted trees and built a rockery. The area was called Joe’s Bridge after local man, Joe Sweetman, who often used to sit there some years ago.


To commemorate the occasion a stone was laid on the site with an inscription, but you'll have to visit the site to find out what it says.


 


The Cache

To work out the cache location find the following information from the inscription on the commemoration stone.

A. The number of vowels in the 6th word.
B. The number of punctuation marks in the two larger scripts
C. The number of letters in the first word carved in the smallest script size
 

Cache location: N 53° 3A.(104*B*B) W 006° 07.(133*C)+A

The final cache location is approximately 2km away. The cache is a quarter litre container. Please upload a photo of yourself doing it just like Joe.

Additional Waypoints
